awd_titl_txt: Exploring lateral photo-Dember effect in two dimensional atomic layer crystals for terahertz generation
awd_abstract_narration:
The efficient generation of long wavelength radiation at the 0.1~10 terahertz region remains a key challenge for the development and deployment of terahertz technology for high speed communication, spectroscopy, and imaging applications. This research project explores a unique lateral photo-Dember effect in 2-dimensional nanomaterials for terahertz generation. The proposed project will open a door to developing new type of compact terahertz sources with a broad range of applications. In addition, the knowledge and techniques acquired through the proposed research can readily be extended to study ultrafast optical physics of other type of 1-dimensional and 2-dimensional nanomaterials. More broadly, the proposed project is highly interdisciplinary and should advance science and technology in areas of nanomaterials, optical science, nanoelectronics, nanophotonics, and device physics. The project also includes an outreach and education program promoting awareness of and interest in nanoscience and nanotechnology among K-12 and undergraduate students.  The knowledge and research findings resulting from this project will be integrated into a number of new nanotechnology courses currently under development that are related to carbon nanotechnology, optical science, and nanophotonics. This project will be further enhanced by proactively recruiting underrepresented students, which can improve the diversity of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics disciplines and workforce.

This research project aim to understand the fundamental lateral photo-Dember effect in 2-dimensional atomic layer crystals including graphene and few layer transition metal dichalcogenides, and to pioneer new terahertz sources based on these 2-dimensional nanomaterials. The project tasks are: (1) to perform fundamental study to thoroughly understand the ultrafast photo-carrier dynamics in graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides; (2) to fabricate and characterize the terahertz emission from metal/2-dimensional nanomaterial junctions; (3) to design new terahertz emitter arrays based on 2-dimensional nanomaterials and test their performance. A combination of advanced optoelectronic characterization techniques for 2-dimensional nanomaterials will be developed and utilized in this project, including scanning photocurrent measurement, ultrafast pump-probe photocurrent measurement, and terahertz time-domain spectroscopy techniques. The success of the project will generate fundamental and detailed understanding of light-matter interaction and ultrafast carrier dynamics in low dimensional nanomaterials. In addition, the finding of the project will truly showcase the advantages of 2-dimensional nanomaterials for unique optoelectronic applications which are not possible in bulk semiconductors.

por.por_cntn:
The efficient generation of long wavelength radiation at the 0.1~10 terahertz (THz) region remains a key challenge for the development and deployment of THz technology for high speed communication, spectroscopy, and imaging applications. Although decades of research and progress have led to considerable advances in conventional THz generation techniques, such as the pulse generation method using a photoconductive Auston switch, CW methods using frequency mixing, and the air-plasma technique, the demands of high power, high efficiency, and compactness motivate further development. The photo-Dember effect is a less commonly exploited THz generation mechanism. It arises from the asymmetric diffusivity of photoexcited electrons and holes, which creates a transient spatial charge distribution and hence dipole radiation. Specifically, in low dimensional nanomaterials, the strong carrier quantum confinement coupled with strong light-matter interaction can lead to the enhancement of transient carrier dynamics, and hence new types of THz sources.

The objective of this proposal is to understand fundamentally the lateral photo-Dember effect in 2D atomic layer crystals including graphene and few layer transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs), and to pioneer new THz sources based on these 2D nanomaterials. Over the course of the project, we develop a novel approach by directly integrating the graphene device with an on-chip Auston switch for THz detection. We successfully confirmed the first direct observation of THz emission from graphene/metal junction due to lateral photo-Dember effect. Second, we also studied the THz emission from the graphene/Si hybrid structure, and observed 1-2 orders of magnitudes enhancement in THz emission. This result could potentially lead to strong broadband THz generation with a relatively simple Auston switch design. Third, we demonstrated an electrically tunable graphene photodetector by exploring the hot carrier tunneling dynamics, and this tunable detector can be used for spectra reconstruction without the need of a prism. The project opens a door to developing new type of compact terahertz sources with a broad range of applications. More broadly, the findings from the project will generate fundamental and detailed understanding of light-matter interaction and ultrafast carrier dynamics in low dimensional nanomaterials.

The project also integrated an outreach and education program promoting awareness of and interest in nanoscience and nanotechnology among K-12 and undergraduate students.  The knowledge and research findings resulting from this project were integrated into a number of new nanotechnology courses that are related to carbon nanotechnology, optical science, and nanophotonics. This project also recruited and trained underrepresented students for improving the diversity of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics disciplines and workforce.
